Description: Rim, body and handle sherd (mended from six fragments) of Attic black-figured pottery lidless lekanis; interior glazed streaky black; on top of rim three rows of messy dots; handle black on outside, reserved on inside; exterior: exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of swan and confronting sirens (of swan under handle, only tail feathers missing; red on wing and tail, to right; of sirens, siren at left complete, with red on face, chest, wing and tail feathers, facing to right; of siren at right, facing left, lower body missing; red on face, chest and wing); incised splinter rosettes with red and dots as filling ornament; below, three careless bands above frieze of rays and blaze around turn to foot. Much chalky included matter in clay.
Producer name: Attributed to the Manner of: The Polos Painter
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1886,0401.1169. For parallels, see Venit 1984, 151-2, figs. 17-22.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B102.31.1-2)
Beazley 1944 / Groups of Early Attic Black Figure (p. 55, no. 3)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 336, no. B397)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 151, note 67, no. 13)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0761) (Phase 1)
